bestBHT.bht: It is better for those who have known the way of righteousness and the holy commandment to not turn back from it. The way of righteousness is the way of truth and Christian doctrine, while the holy commandment refers to the moral law of the gospel. Turning back from the holy commandment means going against the inviolate Gospel that enjoins holiness. Those who have known the way of righteousness and turn back are said to be in a worse state than those who have never known it at all.

Henry Alford: For it were better for them not to have known the way of righteousness than, having known it, to turn back from the holy commandment.
The way of righteousness... the way of truth.
The holy commandment... the moral law of the gospel.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: the way of righteousness—'the way of truth' (2 Peter 2:2). Christian doctrine, and 'the knowledge of the Lord and Saviour."
from the holy commandment—the Gospel which enjoins holiness; in opposition to their corruption. 'Holy,' not that it makes holy, but because it ought to be kept inviolate [TITTMANN]."
delivered—once for all; admitting no turning back.
Albert Barnes: It would have been better for them, for: (1) Then they would not have dishonored the cause of religion as they have now done
If people are resolved on being wicked, they had better never pretend to be good.
If they are to be cast off at last, it had better not be as apostates from the cause of virtue and religion.
John Calvin: He intimates first, how inexcusable they were.
The doctrine of a holy and virtuous life...is yet peculiarly taught to those whom God favors with the light of his gospel.
The faithful also do indeed sin; but as they allow not dominion to sin, they do not fall away from the grace of God.
Philip Schaff: For it were better for them not to have known the way of righteousness, than, having known it, to turn back from the holy commandment delivered to them."
The ‘way of righteousness’ is not quite the same as ‘the Gospel’ or ‘the way of salvation.’ It is a term for Christianity specifically on its ethical side, as a new moral life.

The ‘holy commandment’ is not to be limited either to the commandment known as the ‘new commandment’ or to the Sermon on the Mount. It is the ethical requirement of the Gospel as a whole, the law of life which Christ has left.
John Gill: It would have been a lesser evil, and not so much aggravated: not to have known the way of righteousness."
A large, notional, though not an experimental knowledge, these apostates had of the word and doctrine of righteousness.
It would have been better for them to have been in their former ignorance, either in Judaism, or in Gentilism, since proportionate to a man's light is his guilt, and so his punishment.
John Wesley: The commandment — The whole law of God, once not only delivered to their ears, but written in their hearts.
